newsitem.title: MEXICO: MEXICO PESO ENDS SOFT, ZIGZAGS ON U.S. MKTS.
newsitem.headline: MEXICO PESO ENDS SOFT, ZIGZAGS ON U.S. MKTS.

text.p: The Mexican peso closed weaker across the board on Friday but partially recovered from midsession lows after tracking a sharp slide on the U.S. stock and bond markets, dealers said.

"The peso slid in parallel with the main U.S. market indicators, the Dow Jones and the long bond," a trader said. "The market was skittish and overreacted, however, and recovered after the peso hit 7.86 per dollar."
The benchmark 48-hour peso and its 24-hour stablemate ended 0.75 and 0.9 of a centavo weaker, respectively, at 7.8150/7.8200 and 7.8120/7.8170 per dollar.
The Dow Jones was down 113.12 points to 8,074.88 in late trade, while the U.S. 30-year Treasury bond had declined 45/32 to a yield of 6.63 percent.
Same-day peso contracts had closed earlier 3.5 centavos weaker at 7.8120/7.8170 per dollar.
Dealers said they would pay close attention next week to reaction on the U.S. bond market to inflation data.
"If long bond yields stay above 6.60 percent, the peso will be under pressure," another dealer said.
